00030 from Koo import Rpc
00031 from Koo.Common import Api
00032 from Koo.Common import Help
00033 from FieldPreferencesDialog import *
00034 
00035 from PyQt4.QtGui import *
00036 from PyQt4.QtCore import *
00037 
00038 
00039 ## @brief AbstractFieldWidget is the base class for all field widgets in Koo.
00040 # In order to create a new field widget, that is: a widget that appears in a 
00041 # auto-generated form you need to inherit from this class and implement some
00042 # of it's functions.
00043 #
00044 # The Widget handles a field from a record. You can access the record
00045 # using the property 'record' and the field name using the property 'name'.
00046 #
00047 class AbstractFieldWidget(QWidget):
00048 
00049         ## @brief Creates a new AbstractFieldWidget and receives the following parameters
00050         #  parent:     The QWidget parent of this QWidget
00051         #  view:       Holds the reference to the view the widget is in
00052         #  attributes: Holds some extra attributes such as read-only and others
00053         def __init__(self, parent, view, attributes):
00054                 QWidget.__init__(self, parent)
00055 
00056                 self.attrs = attributes
00057                 self.view = view
00058 
00059                 self._isInitialized = False
00060                 self._isUpToDate = False
00061 
00062                 # Required and readonly attributes are not directly linked to
00063                 # the field states because a widget might not have a record
00064                 # assigned. Also updating the attribute directly in the fields
00065                 # can cause some problems with stateAttributes.
00066                 self._required = self.attrs.get('required', False) not in ('False', '0', False)
00067                 self._readOnly = self.attrs.get('readonly', False) not in ('False', '0', False)
00068                 
00069                 # Find Koo specific attributes that OpenObject's Relax NG doesn't allow
00070                 self.setStyleSheet( eval(self.attrs.get('use', '{}')).get('stylesheet','') )
00071 
00072                 self.defaultReadOnly= self._readOnly
00073                 self.defaultMenuEntries = [
00074                         (_('Set to default value'), self.setToDefault, 1),
00075                 ]
00076 
00077                 # As currently slotSetDefault needs view to be set we use it
00078                 # only in form views.
00079                 if self.view:
00080                         self.defaultMenuEntries.append( (_('Set as default value'), self.setAsDefault, 1) )
00081 
00082                 # self.name holds the name of the field the widget handles
00083                 self.name = self.attrs.get('name', 'unnamed')
00084                 self.record = None
00085 
00086                 # Some widgets might want to change their color set.
00087                 self.colors = {
00088                         'invalid'  : '#FF6969',
00089                         'readonly' : '#e3e3e3', 
00090                         'required' : '#ddddff', 
00091                         'normal'   : 'white'
00092                 }
00093 
00094         def addShortcut(self, keys):
00095                 if not keys:
00096                         return
00097                 shortcut = QShortcut(QKeySequence(keys), self)
00098                 self.connect(shortcut, SIGNAL('activated()'), self.setFocus)
00099 
00100         def initialize(self):
00101                 self.addShortcut( eval(self.attrs.get('use', '{}')).get('shortcut','') )
00102 
00103         def showEvent(self, event):
00104                 if not self._isInitialized:
00105                         self._isInitialized = True
00106                         self.initGui()
00107                         self.initialize()
00108                 if not self._isUpToDate:
00109                         self._isUpToDate = True
00110                         if self.record:
00111                                 self.showValue()
00112                         self.updateColor()
00113                 return QWidget.showEvent(self, event)
00114 
00115         def showHelp(self):
00116                 QApplication.setOverrideCursor( Qt.WaitCursor )
00117                 helpWidget = Help.HelpWidget( self.sender() )
00118                 helpWidget.setLabel( self.attrs.get('string','') )
00119                 helpWidget.setHelp( self.attrs.get('help','') )
00120                 helpWidget.setType( helpWidget.FieldType )
00121                 if self.record:
00122                         # TODO: self.record should be optional
00123                         helpWidget.setFilter( (self.record.group.resource, self.name) )
00124                 helpWidget.show()
00125                 QApplication.restoreOverrideCursor()
00126 
00127         ## @brief This function is called the first time the widget is shown.
00128         #
00129         # It can be used by widgets to initialize GUI elements that are slow to
00130         # execute. The advantage of using this function is that if the user never
00131         # sees the widget (because it's in another tab, for example), it will never
00132         # be called, improving form loading time.
00133         #
00134         # It's ensured that this function is called before any call to showValue() or
00135         # storeValue() happens.
00136         def initGui(self):
00137                 return
00138 
00139         ## @brief Sets the default value to the field.
00140         #
00141         # Note that this requires a call to the server.
00142         def setToDefault(self):
00143                 try:
00144                         model = self.record.group.resource
00145                         res = Rpc.session.call('/object', 'execute', model, 'default_get', [self.attrs['name']])
00146                         self.record.setValue(self.name, res.get(self.name, False))
00147                         self.display()
00148                 except:
00149                         QMessageBox.warning(None, _('Operation not permited'), _('You can not set to the default value here !') )
00150                         return False
00151 
00152         ## @brief Opens the FieldPreferencesDialog to set the current value as default for this field.
00153         def setAsDefault(self):
00154                 if not self.view:
00155                         return
00156                 deps = []
00157                 wid = self.view.widgets
00158                 for wname, wview in self.view.widgets.items():
00159                         if wview.attrs.get('change_default', False):
00160                                 value = wview.record.value(wview.name)
00161                                 deps.append((wname, wname, value, value))
00162                 value = self.record.default( self.name )
00163                 model = self.record.group.resource
00164                 dialog = FieldPreferencesDialog(self.attrs['name'], self.attrs.get('string', self.attrs['name']), model, value, deps)
00165                 dialog.exec_()
00166 
00167 
00168         def updateColor(self):
00169                 if self.record and not self.record.isFieldValid( self.name ):
00170                         self.setColor('invalid')
00171                 elif self._readOnly:
00172                         self.setColor('readonly')
00173                 elif self._required:
00174                         self.setColor('required')
00175                 else:
00176                         self.setColor('normal')
00177 
00178         ## @brief This function is called when the widget has to be Read-Only. 
00179         # When implementing a new widget, please use setEnabled( not ro ) instead 
00180         # of read-only. The gray color gives information to the user so she knows 
00181         # the field can't be modified
00182         def setReadOnly(self, ro):
00183                 self._readOnly = ro
00184                 self.updateColor()
00185 
00186         ## @brief This function returns True if the field is read-only. False otherwise.
00187         def isReadOnly(self):
00188                 return self._readOnly
00189 
00190         ## @brief Updates the background color depending on widget state.
00191         #
00192         # Possible states are: invalid, readonly, required and normal.
00193         def refresh(self):
00194                 self.setReadOnly( self._readOnly )
00195 
00196         ## @brief Use it in your widget to return the widget in which you want the color 
00197         # indicating the obligatory, normal, ... etc flags to be set. 
00198         # By default colorWidget() returns self.
00199         def colorWidget(self):
00200                 return self
00201 
00202         ## @brief Use this function to return the menuEntries your widget wants to show
00203         # just before the context menu is shown. Return a list of tuples in the form:
00204         # [ (_('Menu text'), function/slot to connect the entry, True (for enabled) or False (for disabled) )] 
00205         def menuEntries(self):
00206                 return []
00207 
00208         ## @brief Sets the background color to the widget returned by colorWidget(). 
00209         # name should contain the current state ('invalid', 'readonly', 'required' or 'normal')
00210         #
00211         # The appropiate color for each state is stored in self.colors dictionary.
00212         def setColor(self, name):
00213                 color = QColor( self.colors.get( name, 'white' ) )
00214                 palette = QPalette()
00215                 palette.setColor(QPalette.Active, QPalette.Base, color)
00216                 self.colorWidget().setPalette(palette);
00217 
00218         ## @brief Installs the eventFilter on the given widget so the popup
00219         # menu will be shown on ContextMenu event. Also data on the widget will
00220         # be stored in the record when the widget receives the FocusOut event.
00221         def installPopupMenu( self, widget ):
00222                 widget.installEventFilter( self )
00223 
00224         ## @brief Reimplements eventFilter to show the context menu and store
00225         # information when the widget loses the focus. This function will be
00226         # used on the widget you give to installPopupMenu.
00227         def eventFilter( self, target, event ):
00228                 if event.type() == QEvent.ContextMenu:
00229                         self.showPopupMenu( target, event.globalPos() )
00230                         return True
00231                 if event.type() == QEvent.FocusOut:
00232                         if self.record:
00233                                 self.store()
00234                 return False
00235 
00236         ## @brief Shows a popup menu with default and widget specific
00237         # entries.
00238         def showPopupMenu(self, parent, position):
00239                 entries = self.defaultMenuEntries[:]
00240                 new = self.menuEntries()
00241                 if len(new) > 0:
00242                         entries = entries + [(None, None, None)] + new
00243                 menu = QMenu( parent )
00244                 for title, slot, enabled in entries:
00245                         if title:
00246                                 item = QAction( title, menu )
00247                                 if slot:
00248                                         self.connect( item, SIGNAL("triggered()"), slot )
00249                                 item.setEnabled( enabled )
00250                                 menu.addAction( item )
00251                         else:
00252                                 menu.addSeparator()
00253                 menu.popup( position )
00254 
00255         ## @brief Call this function/slot when your widget changes the
00256         # value. This is needed for the onchange option in the 
00257         # server modules. Usually you'll call it on lostFocus if
00258         # there's a TextBox or on selection, etc.
00259         def modified(self):
00260                 if not self.record:
00261                         return 
00262                 self.store()
00263 
00264         ## @brief Override this function. This will be called by display()
00265         # when it wants the value to be shown in the widget
00266         def showValue(self):
00267                 pass
00268 
00269         ## @brief Override this function. It will be used whenever there
00270         # is no model or have created a new record.
00271         def clear(self):
00272                 pass
00273 
00274         ## @brief This function displays the current value of the field in the record 
00275         # in the widget.
00276         #
00277         # Do not reimplement this function, override clear() and showValue() instead
00278         def display(self):
00279                 if not self.record:
00280                         self._readOnly = True
00281                         self.clear()
00282                         self.refresh()
00283                         return
00284                 self._readOnly = self.record.isFieldReadOnly(self.name)
00285                 self._required = self.record.isFieldRequired(self.name)
00286                 self.refresh()
00287                 if self.isVisible():
00288                         if not self._isInitialized:
00289                                 self._isInitialized = True
00290                                 self.initGui()
00291                                 self.initialize()
00292                         self._isUpToDate = True
00293                         self.showValue()
00294                 else:
00295                         self._isUpToDate = False
00296         
00297         def reset(self):
00298                 self.refresh()
00299 
00300         ## @brief Sets the current record for the widget.
00301         def load(self, record ):
00302                 self.record = record
00303                 self.display()
00304 
00305         ## @brief Stores information in the widget to the record.
00306         # Reimplement this function in your widget.
00307         def storeValue(self):
00308                 pass
00309 
00310         ## @brief Stores information in the widget to the record.
00311         # This is the function you should call when you want the field
00312         # to store information back into the model. This function may
00313         # NOT store information if it has not changed.
00314         def store(self):
00315                 if not self._isUpToDate:
00316                         return
00317                 self.storeValue()
00318 
00319         def saveState(self):
00320                 return QByteArray()
00321 
00322         def restoreState(self, state):
00323                 pass
